dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So, is 3-D printing finally having its billion-dollar moment?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, is three-D printing finally having its billion-dollar moment?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It sure looks that way—Carbon's raising another 300 million, which is huge.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It sure looks that way-Carbon's raising another three hundred million, which is huge.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That's the case even before accounting for the coming $300 million fundraise from 3-D printing unicorn Carbon, which was first reported by PitchBook on Thursday.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and according to Forbes, that would be the largest deal in the industry in five years.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and according to Forbes, that would be the largest deal in the industry in five years.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Carbon's $300 million fundraise would be the largest deal of the past five years among 3-D printing companies, according to the PitchBook analysis, surpassing the same firm's earlier $200 million deal in February 2018.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and it's not just them—Desktop Metal raised 140 million, Markforged got 72 million…
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and it's not just them-Desktop Metal raised one hundred forty million, Markforged got seventy two million...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Metal 3-D printer maker Desktop Metal raised $160 million, reaching a valuation of $1.5 billion; Markforged, which makes 3-D printers for carbon and metal, raised $82 million, hitting a valuation of $820 million; and 3-D printing service provider Fast Radius brought in $48 million, reaching a valuation of $400 million.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And Fast Radius brought in 58 million. All just in the first part of this year.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And Fast Radius brought in fifty eight million. All just in the first part of this year.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Three of the top 10 deals of the past five years have occurred in the first few months of this year, according to the PitchBook analysis: Metal 3-D printer maker Desktop Metal raised $160 million, reaching a valuation of $1.5 billion; Markforged, which makes 3-D printers for carbon and metal, raised $82 million, hitting a valuation of $820 million; and 3-D printing service provider Fast Radius brought in $48 million, reaching a valuation of $400 million.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Which is wild because, like, last year total funding was what, 700 million?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is wild because, like, last year total funding was what, seven hundred million?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: So far this year, 3-D printing companies have attracted $400 million in venture funding, half the $800 million they had garnered in the entirety of last year, and surpassing the $300 million they'd attracted the year before that, according to the PitchBook analysis.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly—and we're already at 200 million so far this year, not even counting Carbon's new round.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly-and we're already at two hundred million so far this year, not even counting Carbon's new round.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: So far this year, 3-D printing companies have attracted $400 million in venture funding, half the $800 million they had garnered in the entirety of last year, and surpassing the $300 million they'd attracted the year before that, according to the PitchBook analysis.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: So if things keep up, we could hit a billion in funding for the first time since… when, 2015 or something?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So if things keep up, we could hit a billion in funding for the first time since... when, twenty fifteen or something?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: If deal flow continued at that rate, it would cross the billion-dollar mark for the first time in five years, even before accounting for the Carbon deal.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's been six years since that happened. That's a pretty big turnaround.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's been six years since that happened. That's a pretty big turnaround.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: If deal flow continued at that rate, it would cross the billion-dollar mark for the first time in five years, even before accounting for the Carbon deal.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And you know, Carbon's valuation could jump to 2.3 billion after this.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And you know, Carbon's valuation could jump to two point three billion after this.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The company is currently valued at $1.7 billion, and could be worth as much as $2.5 billion after the new funding.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Plus they've got that Nike partnership for the Futurecraft midsoles—real industrial use cases now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Plus they've got that Nike partnership for the Futurecraft midsoles-real industrial use cases now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Carbon is best known for its partnership with Adidas, with whom it is partnering on midsoles for the German sportswear giants Futurecraft 4D running shoes.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Uh-huh, it's not just prototyping anymore. Companies are actually manufacturing with this stuff.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Uh-huh, it's not just prototyping anymore. Companies are actually manufacturing with this stuff.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While those dollars are a pittance compared to the funding numbers for healthcare or software companies, they represent a big bump up for 3-D printing, which has been gaining adoption in the industrial sector and has spawned hundreds of new startups.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Which explains why investors like Google and General Motors are already backing Carbon.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which explains why investors like Google and General Motors are already backing Carbon.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Redwood City, California-based company counts Sequoia, GV, Fidelity, General Electric and Adidas Ventures among its existing investors.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Makes sense—when the big players get involved, you know adoption is accelerating.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Makes sense-when the big players get involved, you know adoption is accelerating.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Still, it's a pittance compared to software or biotech funding, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Still, it's a pittance compared to software or biotech funding, right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While those dollars are a pittance compared to the funding numbers for healthcare or software companies, they represent a big bump up for 3-D printing, which has been gaining adoption in the industrial sector and has spawned hundreds of new startups.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: True, but for 3-D printing, this is a massive step up. The sector's maturing, fast.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: True, but for three-D printing, this is a massive step up. The sector's maturing, fast.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While those dollars are a pittance compared to the funding numbers for healthcare or software companies, they represent a big bump up for 3-D printing, which has been gaining adoption in the industrial sector and has spawned hundreds of new startups.

artist_script:
HostA: So, is 3-D printing finally having its billion-dollar moment?
HostB: It sure looks that way—Carbon's raising another 300 million, which is huge.
HostA: Yeah, and according to Forbes, that would be the largest deal in the industry in five years.
HostB: Right, and it’s not just them—Desktop Metal raised 140 million, Markforged got 72 million…
HostA: And Fast Radius brought in 58 million. All just in the first part of this year.
HostB: Which is wild because, like, last year total funding was what, 700 million?
HostA: Exactly—and we’re already at 200 million so far this year, not even counting Carbon’s new round.
HostB: So if things keep up, we could hit a billion in funding for the first time since… when, 2015 or something?
HostA: Yeah, it’s been six years since that happened. That’s a pretty big turnaround.
HostB: And you know, Carbon’s valuation could jump to 2.3 billion after this.
HostA: Plus they’ve got that Nike partnership for the Futurecraft midsoles—real industrial use cases now.
HostB: Uh-huh, it’s not just prototyping anymore. Companies are actually manufacturing with this stuff.
HostA: Which explains why investors like Google and General Motors are already backing Carbon.
HostB: Makes sense—when the big players get involved, you know adoption is accelerating.
HostA: Still, it’s a pittance compared to software or biotech funding, right?
HostB: True, but for 3-D printing, this is a massive step up. The sector’s maturing, fast.
